title.children: Fewer people with psychosocial disability may be added to NDIS, as minister flags 27,000 to be diverted under reforms

image.altText: A black and white graphic of the two men against a Russian map with a red semi-circle behind them.

items.synopsis: Recent developments in Russia raise serious questions about the future of President Vladimir Putin and the war in Ukraine. Join our live Q&A as our experts unpack your questions.

title.children: Is Putin in trouble? Join our experts to discuss the latest struggle for power inside the Kremlin

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Are Russians truly oblivious to wards the death of their men sent to the front line in Ukraine? - Andrew Hi Andrew, Thanks for your question. There are so many factors feeding into the awareness and understanding of Vladimir Putin's war inside his own country. And of course much of that is by his design. Yes, there is a propaganda machine at work that is not reporting death tolls widely or accurately, but there are other dynamics too. Earlier in the year, Western officials said it was likely 200,000 Russians had been injured or killed in the war, with at least 40,000 killed. At the time, the analysis was that Vladimir Putin's support could probably sustain that. And when the partial mobilisation happened in September, we learnt that it targeted ethnic minorities in disadvantaged regions - hardly the centres of the President's power base. So while some Russians are likely oblivious, I don't think that can be said for everyone. I think there are some regions and communities disproportionately impacted who will have buried many of their sons. But in Moscow and St Petersburg, I think there is more tolerance for the deaths because they appear as a number on a page. I wrote about the communities impacted by the mobilisation last year:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Are Russians aware of the death toll?

children.content: Are Russians truly oblivious to wards the death of their men sent to the front line in Ukraine?
- Andrew
Hi Andrew,
Thanks for your question.
There are so many factors feeding into the awareness and understanding of Vladimir Putin's war inside his own country. And of course much of that is by his design.
Yes, there is a propaganda machine at work that is not reporting death tolls widely or accurately, but there are other dynamics too.

Earlier in the year, Western officials said it was likely 200,000 Russians had been injured or killed in the war, with at least 40,000 killed. At the time, the analysis was that Vladimir Putin's support could probably sustain that.
And when the partial mobilisation happened in September, we learnt that it targeted ethnic minorities in disadvantaged regions - hardly the centres of the President's power base.

So while some Russians are likely oblivious, I don't think that can be said for everyone. I think there are some regions and communities disproportionately impacted who will have buried many of their sons. But in Moscow and St Petersburg, I think there is more tolerance for the deaths because they appear as a number on a page.
I wrote about the communities impacted by the mobilisation last year:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Did the failed mutiny actually make Putin's position stronger? The strongest private army and loudest critic of the Kremlin were eliminated, didn’t it play out like Putin would have hoped a potential coup might go? - Marc Hi Marc, thanks for writing in. I've put your question to military strategist Mick Ryan, who writes: The coup ultimately has not made Putin stronger. While it might have removed Wagner as a threat (for now) the weekend was not about overthrowing Putin but more about a cry for help from Prigozhin. That said, the slow reaction of Putin and the security authorities has damaged Putin’s standing and revealed what many Russian experts have been describing for some time as a brittleness in the Russian system. For a far better analysis than I could ever provide, I recommend Peter Tesch’s latest article at the ASPI Strategist. Peter has been, and remains, a superb servant of our nation, was our ambassador to Moscow, and is a very deep and broad expert on Russia issues.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Did the failed mutiny make Putin's position stronger?

children.content: Did the failed mutiny actually make Putin's position stronger? The strongest private army and loudest critic of the Kremlin were eliminated, didn’t it play out like Putin would have hoped a potential coup might go? -
Marc
Hi Marc, thanks for writing in. I've put your question to military strategist
Mick Ryan
, who writes:
The coup ultimately has not made Putin stronger. While it might have removed Wagner as a threat (for now) the weekend was not about overthrowing Putin but more about a cry for help from Prigozhin.

That said, the slow reaction of Putin and the security authorities has damaged Putin’s standing and revealed what many Russian experts have been describing for some time as a brittleness in the Russian system. For a far better analysis than I could ever provide, I recommend
Peter Tesch’s latest article at the ASPI Strategist
. Peter has been, and remains, a superb servant of our nation, was our ambassador to Moscow, and is a very deep and broad expert on Russia issues.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Poland's President Duda expressed some concern over Wagner being so close to his country's border. Should Poland or other neighbouring countries be concerned, could Wagner be used in some shape or form to destabilise the immediate region? - Rafski Hi Rafski, thanks for your question. I've put it to our global affairs editor John Lyons, who writes: Hello Rafski - you're right to raise Poland. Poland is so heavily invested in what happens in Ukraine for many reasons. I don't think Wagner is a particular threat to Poland. I think the real threat to Poland is Russia's general aggression. One thing that really struck me being in Ukraine and Poland recently is how crowded the highway from Poland is with tanks and other military hardware. Poland has become crucial as a launching pad for the continuing defence of Ukraine.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Should Poland be concerned?

children.content: Poland's President Duda expressed some concern over Wagner being so close to his country's border. Should Poland or other neighbouring countries be concerned, could Wagner be used in some shape or form to destabilise the immediate region? -
Rafski
Hi Rafski, thanks for your question. I've put it to our global affairs editor
John Lyons
, who writes:
Hello Rafski - you're right to raise Poland. Poland is so heavily invested in what happens in Ukraine for many reasons.

I don't think Wagner is a particular threat to Poland. I think the real threat to Poland is Russia's general aggression. One thing that really struck me being in Ukraine and Poland recently is how crowded the highway from Poland is with tanks and other military hardware. Poland has become crucial as a launching pad for the continuing defence of Ukraine.

image.altText: People walking in Brisbane's Queen Street Mall

items.synopsis: The latest monthly consumer price indicator shows inflation eased sharply to 5.6 per cent over the 12 months to May, down from 6.8 per cent in April. Follow our live blog for the latest updates.

title.children: Future interest rate rises uncertain as inflation hits 13-month low of 5.6pc

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Here's some reaction from major business groups after annual inflation pulled back to 5.6 per cent May. The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry says the retreat in inflation will bring some comfort to small business. ACCI chief of policy and advocacy David Alexander: “After experiencing 12 interest rate increases, declining consumer spending, and a surge in input costs, it’s good news for small businesses that inflation is returning to its downward trend." “Many small businesses are seeing their costs rise to the point where they have no choice but to increase their prices to maintain operations." Australian Industry Group chief executive Innes Willox says the drop in inflation is encouraging, but more rate hikes will likely be needed. "While encouraging for both households and businesses and bearing in mind that the monthly ABS excludes some items, we are not there yet. " "Sticking on the path to target inflation will require continued restraint in price setting and wage negotiations by businesses, governments and employees." "With GDP growth of just 0.2 per cent in the March quarter, there is very little scope for further slowing without tipping the economy into contraction."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Business reaction to cooler inflation

children.content: Here's some reaction from major business groups after annual inflation pulled back to 5.6 per cent May.
The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry says the retreat in inflation will bring some comfort to small business.
ACCI chief of policy and advocacy David Alexander:
“After experiencing 12 interest rate increases, declining consumer spending, and a surge in input costs, it’s good news for small businesses that inflation is returning to its downward trend."
“Many small businesses are seeing their costs rise to the point where they have no choice but to increase their prices to maintain operations."
Australian Industry Group chief executive Innes Willox says the drop in inflation is encouraging, but more rate hikes will likely be needed.
"While encouraging for both households and businesses and bearing in mind that the monthly ABS excludes some items, we are not there yet. "
"Sticking on the path to target inflation will require continued restraint in price setting and wage negotiations by businesses, governments and employees."
"With GDP growth of just 0.2 per cent in the March quarter, there is very little scope for further slowing without tipping the economy into contraction."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Capital Economics thinks the slowdown in inflation is not fast enough to prevent further rate hikes by the RBA. And Marcel Thieliant, head of Asia Pacific at Capital Economics, believes the RBA's war on inflation could end in recession. "The sharp fall in inflation in May raises the risk that the Reserve Bank of Australia will not raise rates any further at the upcoming meeting in July, but we still think that mounting upside risks to inflation will prompt it to press ahead." "With the labour market still very tight, unit labour cost growth surging and the housing market bouncing bank with a vengeance, we suspect the Reserve Bank will press ahead with another rate hike next week." Capital Economics forecasts the official cash rate will peak at 4.85 per cent by September, and then the Reserve Bank will cut rates next year.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: RBA to press on with rate rises

children.content: Capital Economics thinks the slowdown in inflation is not fast enough to prevent further rate hikes by the RBA.
And Marcel Thieliant, head of Asia Pacific at Capital Economics, believes the RBA's war on inflation could end in recession.

"The sharp fall in inflation in May raises the risk that the Reserve Bank of Australia will not raise rates any further at the upcoming meeting in July, but we still think that mounting upside risks to inflation will prompt it to press ahead."

"With the labour market still very tight, unit labour cost growth surging and the housing market bouncing bank with a vengeance, we suspect the Reserve Bank will press ahead with another rate hike next week."
Capital Economics forecasts the official cash rate will peak at 4.85 per cent by September, and then the Reserve Bank will cut rates next year.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Is it fair to say that, due to the increased cost of rentals, the RBA may have to increase interest rates to make housing more expensive in order to make housing more affordable? Just confirming that is the logic here? - Tim. Hi Tim, You're one of a few keen commenters who have pointed this out. It sounds counterintuitive but you're right — that is exactly the logic here. RBA governor Philip Lowe told a Senate Estimates hearing in Canberra last month that higher interest rates would help alleviate some rental pressures in the short term because it would force people to "economise" on their housing — which translates to either living at home for longer, or getting housemates. Here's what he said: "The way that this ends up fixing itself, unfortunately, is through higher housing prices and higher rents. "Because as rents go up people decide not to move out of home, or you don't have that home office, you [get] a flatmate. "The increase in supply can't happen immediately, but higher prices do lead people to economise on housing. "That's the price mechanism at work. We need more people on average to live in each dwelling, and prices do that." Rents make up a solid chunk of the consumer price index (in fact, Mr Lowe says they're the "single largest" component) and expects rents will remain high for some time. Of course, long term we need to see an increase in housing supply — which Mr Lowe also acknowledged during Estimates. You can read the full story about Mr Lowe's justification for higher rents by my colleagues Gareth Hutchens and Rhiana Whitson below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Are higher interest rates making housing more expensive so it will then be more affordable?

featuredLink.title: Higher rents will help reduce rental stress by encouraging people to 'economise' on housing, RBA governor says

children.content: Is it fair to say that, due to the increased cost of rentals, the RBA may have to increase interest rates to make housing more expensive in order to make housing more affordable? Just confirming that is the logic here?
- Tim
Hi Tim,
You're one of a few keen commenters who have pointed this out. It sounds counterintuitive but you're right — that is exactly the logic here.
RBA governor Philip Lowe
told a Senate Estimates hearing in Canberra last month that higher interest rates would help alleviate some rental pressures in the short term because it would
force people to "economise" on their housing
— which translates to either living at home for longer, or getting housemates.
Here's what he said:
"The way that this ends up fixing itself, unfortunately, is through higher housing prices and higher rents.
"Because
as rents go up people decide not to move out of home, or you don't have that home office, you [get] a flatmate
"The increase in supply can't happen immediately, but
higher prices do lead people to economise on housing
"That's the price mechanism at work. We
need more people on average to live in each dwelling
, and prices do that."
Rents make up a solid chunk of the consumer price index (in fact, Mr Lowe says they're the "single largest" component) and expects rents will remain high for some time.
Of course, long term we need to see an increase in housing supply — which Mr Lowe also acknowledged during Estimates.
You can read the full story about Mr Lowe's justification for higher rents by my colleagues Gareth Hutchens and Rhiana Whitson below:
